;泰蒂安娜·贝扎托斯纳 (Tetiana Bezatosna) 用手电筒穿过烧焦的废墟，返回自己的公寓。它遭到俄罗斯轰炸的重创。这位两个孩子的乌克兰母亲对重建的希望渺茫。

;

;她位于东北部城市哈尔科夫的家是乌克兰数十万处遭受战争破坏的民用财产之一，其修复工作花费了巨额费用预计需要数十年时间。

;

;在俄罗斯入侵的第二年里，对乌克兰城市的不间断轰炸使修复巨大损失变得更加复杂，这与欧洲几十年来所见的情况不同。

;

; p>;

;突显了贝扎托斯纳萨尔蒂夫卡郊区居民所说的缓慢的恢复速度——布满炮弹的建筑物和被毁坏的商店的地狱般的景象——盘旋在受损地点上空的手提钻和起重机基本上闲置着。

;

;“我们预计不会很快回到这里，”44 岁的 Bezatosna 走向她九楼的公寓。

;

;“看到这一切非常艰难和痛苦。”

;< p>;当她走过烧焦的公寓时，碎玻璃在她的鞋底下嘎吱作响，她用手机的手电筒照着居民留下的物品——废弃的书籍、发霉的厨具、乐高玩具。

;

;在一层楼，临时柱子支撑着混凝土上千疮百孔的楼梯。

;

;贝扎托斯纳逃离了萨尔蒂夫卡，这是一个曾经繁荣的哈尔科夫郊区，拥有数十万人口，在俄罗斯最初的攻击中，贝扎托斯纳首当其冲。入侵于 2022 年 2 月开始。

;

;去年 9 月哈尔科夫地区大部分地区解放后，她的家人返回。被迫租下另一个地方，他们从公寓里拿出了所有能抢救出来的东西，包括半烧毁的洗衣机和浴缸。

;

;大楼入口处挂着一个牌子，上面写着：“请勿进入， ”

;

;流离失所的居民张贴这个标志主要是为了防止窃贼，他们在两个艰难的选择之间左右为难。

;

;尽管条件危险，但有些人还是不顾一切地想搬回来。敦促政府紧急修复。包括贝扎托斯纳在内的其他人要求拆除这座不稳定的建筑，并在同一地点建造一座新建筑。

;

;“乌克兰必须在战争期间开始重建，以支持其后方，”奥里西亚·卢采维奇 (Orysia Lutsevych) 说，伦敦查塔姆研究所俄罗斯和欧亚项目副主任。

;

;“尽管每天都有导弹袭击，但乌克兰人并没有大量离开该国。为了留在乌克兰，他们需要住房和工作。”

;

;除了房屋之外，战争还摧毁了数千所学校、医院和工厂，以及重要的能源设施、粮仓和海港。

;

;今年早些时候，世界银行表示，乌克兰十年内的重建成本将达到 4110 亿美元，是其 2022 年 GDP 的 2.6 倍。

;

;随着战争每月造成新的损失，数十亿美元的损失将持续到 2022 年。添加到估计中。 6 月在伦敦举行的一次会议上，乌克兰总理丹尼斯·什米加尔 (Denys Shmygal) 表示，重建的总体成本“将会增加”。

;

;乌克兰去年饱受战争摧残的经济出现萎缩，迫切需要资金来进行紧急修复。长期重建援助取决于包括美国和欧盟在内的盟友愿意投入多少资金。

;

;该国正在寻求吸引私人投资，战后重建预计将使乌克兰成为观察家称之为世界上最大的建筑工地。

;

;来自世界各地的公司预计将参加 11 月在波兰举行的第二届“重建乌克兰”贸易展。

;

;“乌克兰的复苏”乌克兰成为当今欧洲最大的经济项目。”其网站援引总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基的话说。

;

;在靠近俄罗斯边境的哈尔科夫市，市长伊戈尔·捷列霍夫表示，战争已经结束。 15 万人无家可归，约 5,000 栋建筑物受损。其中约500栋多层建筑严重受损，无法修复。

;

;他估计重建费用为95亿美元，称这个数字“非常近似”。

;< p>;等到战争结束才进行重建是不可接受的，他说，并补充说“公民需要返回家园。”

;

;但许多人担心俄罗斯的空袭，他们认为这是针对俄罗斯的空袭让他们的城市变得不适合居住，并阻碍了本已微不足道的重建工作。

;

;贝扎托斯纳说，在持续的战争中，“我不知道如何重建”。

;

;在萨尔蒂夫卡，居民们回到了未受战争蹂躏的公寓楼，但由于随机袭击，没有一个角落是安全的。

;

;贝扎托斯纳说，她的公寓在被砸坏前一个月才进行了翻修。她说，她在哈尔科夫的朋友设法修复了她在战争中受损的房子，但又被另一次罢工摧毁了。

;

;“那么告诉我，重建的意义是什么？”她说。

;香港mpox病例的上升趋势是Covid放宽后的延迟爆发-专家表示，19 日实施了旅行限制，并警告说，在最近的病例激增之后，更多的感染可能会从中国大陆蔓延。

;

;专家们表示，由于该病毒不太可能引起社区爆发，因此对普通民众的威胁仍然很低说，敦促当局允许大多数症状较轻的麻疹患者在家中隔离，而不必留在医院。

;

;但卫生部周五表示，目前隔离患者的做法医院符合世界卫生组织 (WHO) 的建议，也是保护公众所必需的。

;

;政府发言人表示，有关这些措施不相称或不必要的建议“对于阻止麻疹感染的传播适得其反”香港”，这样的言论“从公共卫生角度来看是站不住脚的，也是不负责任的”。

;

;Mpox（以前称为猴痘）一直受到关注，因为香港自上个月以来已报告了 26 例感染病例，即 3 例。 -占该市迄今为止 34 例病例总数的四分之一。最近的病例中有一半以上没有旅行史，这表明他们是在当地感染的。

;

;到目前为止，这种疾病主要局限于该市的男男性行为者社区。;

;

;大陆7月新增病例491例，引起世界卫生组织关注。它在本周早些时候的最新MPO报告中指出，在大陆“持续社区传播”的推动下，西太平洋地区病例“显着增加”，而大多数国家的传播水平较低。 p>;

;随着疫苗接种中心的开放，“无需对香港 MPOX 病例激增感到恐慌”

;

;香港大学微生物学系临床助理教授 Siddharth Sridhar 博士表示，病例数量的增加尽管去年夏天全球病例开始激增，但去年年底放宽与大流行相关的旅行措施后，边境两侧的 MPOX 感染数量有所增加。

;

;“随着国际旅行的增加， -香港和内地的高危人群更有可能接触MPOX，”他说。 “如果内地持续爆发，跨境病例是可以预料的。”

;

;去年7月，在疫情发生国报告感染病例后，世界卫生组织宣布MPOX为国际关注的突发公共卫生事件。该病并非地方病。到目前为止，已有 113 个国家报告病例，其中大部分位于美洲和欧洲。全球警报已于五月结束。

;

;传染病专家林伟信博士表示，他相信香港和内地在全球病例激增之初并未受到太大影响，因为该地区仍受到大流行的保护-相关旅行措施。

;

;香港将于周四开设专门的mpox疫苗接种中心

;

;旅行恢复后，该地区开始出现感染。

;

;Sridhar同意可能会有更多的MPO病例从大陆传播到城市，但他认为这不会对整体公共卫生构成重大威胁。

;

;“我们必须现实一点。除了mpox之外，还有其他类型的传染病……只要有社交互动和跨境旅行，就有可能发生[传播]。”他说。

;

;“对普通人群的风险香港大学微生物学系系主任杜启宏教授对报告病例迅速上升表示担忧，新增病例激增过去一周几乎每天都有病例。

;

;中国需要加大力度遏制日益严重的 MPOX 疫情

;

;相比之下，该市的前 8 例病例是在 9 月份以来的 10 个月内出现的

;

;“当邻近地区出现更多病例时，香港出现更多病例的机会自然会更高，”他说。

;

;但传染病专家林说病毒从一个地区传播到另一个地区的速度取决于男男性行为者的网络，他们占了该市除一例之外的所有病例，并且在最近的全球疫情中占了大多数。

;

;他表示，根据过去对其他性传播疾病传播的研究，本地网络与内地和海外的接触并不频繁。

;

;不过，他同意来自不同地域的人之间的性接触不能排除起源。

;

;香港录得第五例猴痘病例，敦促高危人群接种疫苗

;

;香港卫生当局上个月警告称，当地高危人群中爆发了猴痘疫情病例激增后的危险群体。自去年十月开始自愿接种计划后，设立了专门的疫苗接种中心。

;

;为了遏制本地传播，政府应遵循国际准则，允许mpox患者在家中隔离，而不是在医院隔离。斯里达尔说，这将鼓励人们接受检测。

;

;他补充说，人们可能不会寻求医疗救助，因为他们知道，如果他们的病毒检测呈阳性，他们将不得不住院数周。

;

; >;

;香港目前在公立医院隔离猴痘患者，直到“所有传染性病变得到解决”并且他们不再具有传染性，但没有说明具体时间。

;

;香港当局确认了第四例猴痘病例正如专家警告的那样，还会有更多病例

;

;Sridhar 表示，只有出现更严重症状（例如剧烈疼痛，需要药物治疗）的 MPOX 患者才需要住院治疗。

;

;31 岁的商人 Kenneth Kwok 表示去年9月，他被确诊为该市首例MPO病例后，在医院住了大约两周，尽管他的症状很轻微。直到伤口干涸、结痂并脱落后，他才被释放。

;

;他的生殖器部位出现溃疡，面部、身体和四肢出现皮疹，但他说这“比痤疮温和”。

;

;“我没有感到任何不适……就像我无缘无故地占据了医院的空间一样，”他说。

;人民币今年已贬值至接近 10 月份以来的最低水平，许多人内地公民纷纷涌向香港，寻求高收益的银行存款、保险和投资产品以及美元的安全。

;

;来自北京的史先生在香港旅游区的中国银行（香港）分行工作。热点地区尖沙咀，周五早上7.30开立银行账户。由于其他分行的网上预约已经被订满，他决定在那里排队。随着上午 9 点开门时间的临近，已有 30 多人直奔门口。

;

;“我打算在香港为我的孩子购买保险，”不愿透露姓名的史说。以他的姓氏。 “由于最近人民币贬值和香港利率上升，我也在考虑购买一些美元和港币。”

;

;同一队列中，来自江苏省苏州市的陈女士表示他正在寻求购买一份保险以实现投资多元化。 “你不应该把所有资产放在一个篮子里，这就是我来这里的原因。”

;

;中国经济健康状况在六月和七月恶化，贸易、通胀和贷款下降，而国内外需求萎缩。该国正面临信心危机，因为其零敲碎打的重振经济增长的方法令投资者感到失望，从而令人民币汇率承压。

;

;人民币兑美元汇率今年已贬值 5.4%，较上年贬值 7%。过去 12 个月。据路透社报道，周四离岸汇率暴跌至 7.3451 美元兑 9 个月低点，而在岸人民币则创下 11 月份以来的最低水平，为每美元 7.3008 元。

;

;外国投资者已买入 7 美元高盛表示，本月已有 100 亿美元资金退出境内股市。根据本周向客户提供的报告，这家华尔街银行预测，到 2024 年底，人民币兑美元汇率将从 2023 年底的 6.98 元贬至 1 美元兑 7.2 元。

;

;汇丰银行等香港商业银行鉴于银行间市场上贷方之间的借贷成本飙升，这些银行正在悬而未决地采取利润丰厚的激励措施来吸引更多客户存款。其他银行则提供周日银行服务，以满足大陆客户的需求。

;

;汇丰银行为新的高净值客户提供高达 10% 的存款利率，而其他竞争对手银行则为新客户提供 4% 至 8% 的存款利率。新鲜存款。目前，中国大陆的银行为类似定期存款账户支付的年利率约为 1.25% 至 1.65%。

;

;香港向中国大陆游客销售的新人寿保险保单销售额猛增 28 倍，达到 96.1 亿港元（根据保险业监管局公布的数据，第一季度同比增长 12.3 亿美元。

;

;内地游客回流提振香港零售地产市场

;

;“更多内地客户独立货币分析师 Jasper Lo 表示，他们会来香港将人民币兑换成港元或美元存款，或购买这些货币的投资产品作为对冲。 “投资者可以享受香港银行提供的更高利率和潜在的货币收益。这是一个很好的多元化战略。”

;

;咨询公司 Horizo​​ns 表示，在中国的资本管制下，大陆居民每年向境外转移的金额不得超过 5 万美元。每人每年境外ATM取款限额为10万元。声明称，本地和外国游客可以携带 2 万元人民币的现金进出中国，而更高的金额将需要更多文件。

;

;Lo 认为，人民币兑美元还有贬值至 7.5 元的空间。中期。然而，人民币兑美元不太可能达到7.80的“恐慌水平”。人民币上次与港元实现平价是在 2007 年，当时全球金融危机爆发之前。

;

;“在经历了几个月相对较快的贬值之后，北京肯定对[人民币]波动很敏感。”陆挺等野村经济学家表示。 “北京担心持续贬值将引发更大规模的资本外流，从而损害国内消费和投资。”

;

;上海和深圳等一线城市的房价正在下降，部分原因是这些因素他们在周五的一份报告中表示，试图出售香港房屋并将资金转移到海外的高净值人士。

;

;人民币疲软给今年访问香港的人带来了新的动力。自一月份边境全面重新开放以来，包括汇丰银行、恒生银行和东亚银行 (BEA) 在内的银行已在周日维持部分分行的营业，以满足银行业务的需求。

;

;“这些努力取得了成功”，BEA 发言人表示。 “值得注意的是，上半年新入银行跨境客户数量高于Covid-19之前的水平。”

;

;中国银行（香港）开立的新账户数量1-4月，跨境客户数量同比增长5倍。也较2019年同期增长44%。

;

;渣打银行表示，在大湾区，1月至6月客户在渣打银行开立的新账户数量已超过2022年的总数。汇丰银行表示，第二季度非居民新账户数量是 2019 年同期的两倍。

;

;华侨银行香港的中国大陆客户新账户数量第一季度增长了 12 倍与 2022 年同期相比，今年上半年的增长率为 50%。银行发言人表示，他们寻求财富多元化、进入国际市场和外汇机会。

;

;新加坡星展银行 (DBS Bank) 旗下子公司该消费银行集团执行董事 Amy Kwan 表示，该银行今年的新开户数量与疫情前的水平相比，每月平均增加 60%。

;

;“中国大陆个人经常出于个人或商业目的前往香港可能会发现拥有本地银行账户很方便，”她说。 “可以满足日常银行业务需求，如取款、货币兑换、支付孩子的海外教育费和学费。”

;当他咯咯笑的乘客从后面遮住眼睛时，一名年轻的科威特人戏剧性地摇动车把司机在一条狭窄车道的拐弯处猛冲着摩托车，对一辆轻便摩托车冲向他带来的潜在危险感到高兴。

;

;现在是泰国芭堤雅晚上 9 点，夜间表演才刚刚开始。

;< p>;“他们就这样一圈又一圈地转，直到凌晨 3 点或 4 点，”女按摩师艾米说道。 “他们不是坏人，他们没有喝醉——我不认为他们吸食大麻，”艾米补充道，只透露了一个名字。 “但他们还是婴儿。他们一定是喝了太多母乳了。”

;

;就在她说话的时候，另一支自行车车队在她的按摩店旁流下了眼泪，每辆自行车上都挤着三名乘客：科威特男孩赛车手意见不一，这对他们来说是一种滋扰。芭堤雅这座城市长期以来一直欢迎世界各地的游客，但似乎有点不确定如何应对友善而热闹的骑自行车的新客人。

;

;他们的铅笔胡须，甚至更细的胳膊和腿，都证明了这群夏季新移民的年轻和缺乏经验。

;

;当地人说，他们大多数年龄在 18 至 21 岁之间，自 7 月以来已有数千人来到这里。为了躲避科威特的酷暑，他们将留在泰国，直到九月初新的大学学期开始。

;

;当然，芭堤雅也很热，但不像科威特那么热，那里的水银可以推动超过 50 摄氏度（122 华氏度）。

;

;在泰国芭堤雅的冰箱中发现一具外国人肢解尸体

;

;科威特学生多年来一直来到芭堤雅，但去年大流行后边境重新开放后，他们的人数激增。

;

;在社交媒体和年轻人对骑车回家的热爱的推动下，对摩托车的迷恋也有所增长。

;

;每晚警察在学生居住的芭堤雅街道上进行拦截，但未能改变科威特游客的风险分析。事故数量也没有增加——本月一名游客在一次车祸中差点失去一条腿。

;

;7 月 14 日至 8 月 15 日期间，警察向科威特骑手开出 800 张超速罚单，扣押了 272 辆自行车，并罚款 153 辆。芭堤雅交警在一份声明中表示，自行车店老板向无照的人出租车辆。

;

;游客都是年轻人，按照泰国的标准，他们都很富有，他们几乎无一例外都想骑这辆自行车。夏天的必备配件——轻便摩托车或摩托车，通常不戴头盔。

;

;他们的滑稽动作被社交媒体渲染得更加精彩。

;

;“每个人都在家里通过 Snapchat 观看比赛，” 21 岁的苏丹是科威特市的一名技术学院学生。 “是的，这有点危险，但我们不在乎。现在家里的每个人都想来这里。”

;

;

;

;芭堤雅是泰国最有风险的度假胜地，以无拘无束的夜生活而闻名，这也是吸引数百万游客的原因之一每年。

;

;但是科威特的穆斯林人群并不是来酒吧或夜总会的。相反，他们在 Soi Yen Sabai 周围预订了酒店，这是一条狭窄的小巷，遍布阿拉伯餐馆和咖啡馆、旅行社和自行车租赁店，其娱乐活动大部分是自制的。

;

;在地下通道附近的宽阔道路周围，这是对危险、即兴且高度非法的摩托车街头比赛的最大胆尝试。

;

;与《亚洲本周》分享的视频显示，在入口处设立检查站后，学生们排着长队被警察拘留。前往他们扎营的道路。

;

;其他图像显示，失去控制的骑手所受的伤害越来越严重。据报道，科威特骑自行车的人在与泰国人的车辆刮擦或碰撞后也发生过几次打斗。

;

;但令当地人感到震惊的不仅仅是自行车比赛，因为社交媒体鼓励游客突破可接受的界限。

;

;上周分享的一段隐藏摄像头视频据称显示一名持枪男子在俯瞰芭堤雅的热门家庭观景点搜查一群科威特男子。

;

;该视频结果是一群科威特学生使用假武器恶作剧 - 为国内日益增长的社交媒体受众提供的内容。

;

;尽管如此，距离新大学学期开始还有一周，几乎没有迹象表明

;

;“我们来这里是因为科威特现在太热了，食物很好，酒店也很便宜，”21 岁的工科学生奥马尔·阿里 (Omar Ali) 说道来自科威特技术学院。 “这对我们来说非常好......我们的钱在这里很充裕。”

;

;芭堤雅灵活的旅游业很乐意帮助他们消费，感谢淡季的到来，收入仍在从长期的恢复中恢复，全球大流行的艰难岁月。

;

;“我会说足够多的阿拉伯语，可以拿走他们的钱，”街上一位要求匿名的摩托车租赁店老板开玩笑说。 “我不明白为什么人们会抱怨这些孩子，因为他们是唯一给我们带来生意的人……现在是淡季，如果没有这些孩子，生意就会非常冷淡。”

;

;泰国旅游局他们对新市场始终保持警惕，因为他们的目标是今年接待 2500 万人次入境游客，但仍比疫情爆发前的高峰期少 40%。

;

;印度人、马来西亚人和香港人纷纷回流。俄罗斯人仍然是常客，特别是当人们试图避免被征召入伍参加入侵乌克兰的战斗时，而中国仍然是游客数量最多的国家——尽管与新冠疫情爆发前相比有所下降。

;

;据中国官方媒体报道，8 月第一周，有 95,581 名来自中国的游客抵达泰国，比 1 月至 8 月初的 1,589 万人次游客增加了数量，为泰国经济注入了数十亿美元。

;

;旅游业占泰国经济的比重专家表示，一旦算上间接支出，该支出将占该国经济的 12% 至 20%。

;

;泰国央行行长 Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput 于 8 月 16 日表示，尽管存在地缘政治不确定性和国内经济陷入僵局，但泰国经济正在复苏政治。

;

;泰国已在看守政府统治下三个多月了，因为在 5 月份的民意调查中获得最多席位的选举获胜的前进党已被阻止组建新政府。

;

; >;

;“整体经济正在消费和旅游业的推动下复苏，”Sethaput 表示，并补充说，在旅游业的帮助下，第一季度经济同比增长了 2.7%。

;

;今年在两国结束长期外交争端后，沙特阿拉伯成为新的游客来源国，向游客和大手笔投资者敞开了泰国的大门。

;

;其他中东游客 - 包括科威特人——泰国在他们的地图上出现的时间更长，因为泰国是一个相对凉爽的避难所，可以躲避国内炎热的夏季气温。它也是顶级的医疗旅游地点，产业价值超过 10 亿美元。

;

;回到 Soi Yen Sabai，奥马尔·阿里 (Omar Ali) 露出令人放松的笑容，消除了对被捕或受伤的担忧。

;< h3>;“我想尝试一下”：泰国大麻对亚洲游客的吸引力;

;他一边走向轻便摩托车，一边不停地抽烟，而一位朋友的脚踝因前一天尾气烧伤而缠着绷带，一瘸一拐速度跟上。

;

;他们是一对快乐的学生，他们的青春似乎为他们披上了盔甲，以应对即将到来的夜晚骑行的风险。

;

;“这是最好的假期。我们所有的朋友都在这里，我们有自由，明年我们肯定会回来。”他说。

;Shein is the most downloaded shopping app on South Africa's Google Play store. And it isn't even trying that hard.

;

;The Singapore-based fast-fashion brand launched in the country at the foot of the continent during the Covid-19 pandemic and is expanding via word of mouth and by offering first-time buyer discounts. It has already caused such a stir that local retailers are spooked and regulators are investigating if it has exploited import tax loopholes when sending parcels to shoppers.

;

;Taahira Khumalo, a 24 year-old receptionist in Johannesburg, says she now buys all her clothes online and Shein is a brand she keeps on returning to, lured by its competitive prices, on-trend fashion and speed of delivery.

;

;“Shein offers really good discounts and I don't wait long for my parcels to arrive,” she said. “Since the pandemic, technology has improved and now I really don't need to leave the comfort of my home to shop.”

;

;Chinese fast-fashion rivalry spills into courtroom as Temu sues Shein

;

;Shein, founded in China, is gaining a foothold in a nascent e-commerce market in the most industrialised country in Africa and is squaring up to US giants Walmart Inc. and Amazon.com Inc., who want to do the same.

;

;

;

;Walmart has tried to win local hearts the traditional way, buying into domestic retail group Massmart Holdings Ltd. more than a decade ago in an expensive move that so far has failed to live up to expectations. Amazon, which has been providing web services in the country of about 60 million people since 2004, is expected to launch its e-commerce delivery business in South Africa in coming months.

;

;With rapidly growing populations but little formal retail and even less internet shopping, many retailers know they will eventually have to figure out how to make Africa work for them – and South Africa is the most obvious place to start.

;

;“Amazon and Shein are going to accelerate online shopping in South Africa beyond recognition,” said Anthony Thunström, chief executive officer of The Foschini Group Ltd., a local retailer that owns Jet, a discount clothing chain. “South Africa has been very slow adopting digital or online shopping, so I think the competition's good.”

;

;South Africa has a growing middle class, nearly three quarters of the country has internet access and more people live in concentrated urban areas than in most other nations in the region. E-commerce makes up about 4 per cent of retail in the country meaning there are potential riches to be won.

;

;Early mover advantage hasn't really helped Walmart though. When the US retailer first bought into Massmart, which sells clothes, fridges and washing machines alongside tinned foods, it had ambitions to expand with stores across Africa. But subpar infrastructure and difficulties finding good real estate has dimmed that dream.

;

;Instead, in the last three years, it has focused on building its South African online sales and sent Sylvester John, one of its e-commerce experts, to Johannesburg with the goal to make Massmart South Africa's top general merchandise website with same-day fulfilment. Massmart is already revamping its websites and the redesigns are focused on ensuring they're formatted for mobile devices first, instead of desktop. That's because of the strong preference of South African consumers to browse and shop online on their mobile devices, according to John.

;

;Last year the value of goods sold online by Massmart rose more than 90 per cent to 2.3 billion rand (US$120 million), helping justify Walmart's decision to buy out the unit in preparation to go head-to-head with arch rival Amazon. Though it has yet to set a firm date for its retail launch in the country, Amazon has been advertising for local recruits in recent months. The Seattle-based company won permission in June to continue building a local headquarters near Cape Town after a halt due to a dispute with an indigenous group over the land's traditional use.

;

;

;

;Global retailers' inroads into South Africa come even as the country's antitrust regulator examines how e-commerce prices are formulated and as the country battles with erratic electricity supply which is severely hampering economic growth.

;

;“Africa has shown its ability to leapfrog when it comes to technology – we've seen this in online banking and mobile money and I think we are seeing it in purchases made with apps,” said Alec Abraham, an analyst at Sasfin Securities in Johannesburg. “While the South African economy is currently floundering, getting big players like this putting a foot in the door demonstrates the potential that sits within this market.”

;

;Chinese budget shopping app Temu opens in Europe amid rapid expansion

;

;Local retailers are already trying to get ahead of the latest global scramble for South Africa, expanding both what they offer online and how quickly they can deliver orders. Thunström's TFG recently launched its fashion and lifestyle shopping platform, Bash, in just nine months.

;

;“We realised that the future battle was going to be against the Sheins and Amazons of the world,” he said. “Normally this takes two years, but we knew we had to push to do it quicker than that and do it well.”

;

;There are some growing concerns, however, about whether all retailers will operate on a level playing field. South Africa's local industry association as well as the textile union have already complained to the government that they suspect Shein is possibly exploiting customs tax loopholes.

;

;

;

;“We don't mind competition as long as it's by the rules,” said Pieter Erasmus, CEO of Pepkor Holdings Ltd., Africa's largest clothing retailer.

;

;Shein complies with all local laws and regulations and remains open to engage and cooperate with the South African government, a spokesperson said, adding that the retailer finds the local market interesting.

;

;Paying far more than expected for her Shein order to pass through South African customs was Agnes Rammutla's recent experience. The 25-year-old dentist has been buying from Shein for about a year. There was no glitch with her other six orders, but this time local authorities made her stump up more in custom duties before releasing the parcel.

;

;“Like me, all my friends buy online, but I guess there can be a risk,” Rammutla said.

;A silver lining could yet emerge for Philippines-Vietnam ties from an increased regional focus on outwardly aggressive Chinese activities in the South China Sea, analysts say, as the common threat both countries face brings them closer together.

;

;But before any enhancements to maritime security cooperation between the two Southeast Asian nations can occur, they urgently need to find common ground on handling their overlapping claims in the resource-rich waterway, experts say.

;

;Tensions flared this month when Chinese coastguard ships blocked and fired a water cannon at Philippine vessels on a resupply mission to troops deployed on the BRP Sierra Madre vessel in the disputed Spratly Islands.

;

;Why is a rusty old Philippine warship involved in the South China Sea dispute?

;

;Manila ran the World War II-era ship aground there in the late 1990s, to help assert Philippine sovereignty.

;

;Following the recent water-cannon incident, President Ferdinand Marcos Jnr spoke of the importance of the Philippines' growing ties with Vietnam, saying that maritime cooperation would be a “very big step” for the two countries' ties.

;

;“Now that we are going to start discussions on the agreement that we have between the Philippines and Vietnam, I think it is a very important part of our relationship, and it will bring an element of stability to the problems we are now seeing in the South China Sea,” said Marcos, according to a statement by his Presidential Communications Office.

;

;As the two countries seek to strengthen ties amid China's growing assertiveness, they must tackle strategic challenges that have historically impeded their relationship, particularly after the appointment of former president Rodrigo Duterte, who advocated for Manila to form closer ties with Beijing during his 2016-2022 term, moving away from Washington.

;

;A violent clash between Vietnamese fishermen and the Philippine navy in 2017 did not help relations, and the progress made in previous talks appeared to falter amid the Philippines' radical change in foreign policy under Duterte.

;

;Vietnam and the Philippines are among several Southeast Asian nations directly involved in the South China Sea dispute that reject Beijing's “nine-dash line” claim to around 90 per cent of the waterway.

;

;The line – literally made up of nine long dashes – first appeared on Chinese maps in 1953, based on a map with an 11-dash line issued by the Nationalists in 1947.

;

;China has long asserted that its territorial claims over disputed shoals and other features in the sea – based on so-called historic rights – allow it to draw straight baselines to create a vast coastal jurisdiction.

;

;The Southeast Asian claimants, despite their internal differences, hold a common position that maritime claims must be based on the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (Unclos), which was signed by over 150 nations. The claims made by China – itself a signatory – do not adhere to the convention.

;

;Since entering office, Marcos has taken a stronger stance on Beijing, and rekindling ties with Vietnam appears to be part of a larger strategy of not solely relying on the West to deal with China, but working alongside neighbouring states as well.

;

;What's behind Philippine Senate's bipartisan support for firmer China policy?

;

;After a number of meetings between Marcos and Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, the two nations held the 10th meeting of their high-level Joint Permanent Working Group on Maritime and Ocean Concerns in Vietnam in May, to deepen bilateral cooperation.

;

;“[Marcos'] government policy towards the South China Sea is no longer about how China will react to things that the Philippines will be doing,” said Aries Arugay, a visiting fellow at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.

;

;“Under the past administration, it appeared as if the Philippines was walking on eggshells, not doing anything that would somehow cause irritation on the part of China,” he said. “But we can see that ship has already sailed under this new administration.”

;

;Although Vietnam sees the current Manila administration as more trustworthy than Duterte's, strategically it is likely to remain a lot more cautious and subdued in its approach to China, according to Huynh Tam Sang, a lecturer at the Ho Chi Minh City University of Social Sciences and Humanities.

;

;“Despite the Philippines and Vietnam's strengthened ties to jointly weather maritime issues in the South China Sea, Vietnam has tight ideological connections with China and the two neighbours are entrenched in a comprehensive strategic partnership.

;

;“A 'balanced' stance when it comes to great-power politics may stymie Vietnam's concrete efforts to effectively engage with the Philippines,” added Huynh, noting that Vietnam may be more inclined to work with Manila if activities and policies were not directly targeted towards China.

;

;On the Philippine side of the equation, some legislators may argue that Vietnam is untrustworthy because it is under communist rule like China, but they are in the minority, according to Collin Koh, a research fellow at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies (RSIS) in Singapore.

;

;“Generally, the conduct of interstate relations within Asean itself has very much been predicated on pragmatism more than anything else,” he added.

;

;Arugay said that while similar goals in the South China Sea were likely to trump ideological differences, the bigger issue lay in whether the Philippines and Vietnam could come to terms with their own respective claims.

;

;In May, Vietnam criticised a Chinese research ship, as well as a coastguard vessel from the Philippines, for separate actions that Hanoi said violated the country's sovereign rights.

;

;“The fact of the matter is that some of their claims are still overlapping,” Arugay said. “This further cooperation can actually thaw some of the issues between the two that may have prevented them from deeper cooperation in the past.”

;

;Did the Philippines ever agree to move its grounded South China Sea warship?

;

;Huynh concurred, saying that narrowing the scope of differences between the two countries was critical if they were of a mind to collaborate.

;

;“Cooperation in fields ranging from joint patrols to military industry partnerships to coastguard coordination might benefit both sides,” he said.

;

;A de facto alliance between Vietnam and the Philippines might also go a long way in challenging Beijing's growing footprint in the South China Sea.

;

;“Asean needs to have better unity when it comes to negotiating with China on conduct, and for that what needs to be done is to resolve intra-Asean disputes within the South China Sea first,” RSIS' Koh said.

;

;“A divided Asean is always a good thing for China, as it makes it difficult for the member states to coalesce against Beijing on these issues.”

;Niger's self-declared military leader on Saturday proposed a return to democracy within three years.

;

;General Abourahamane Tiani, the leader of last month's coup, said he had given the government 30 days to define a framework for a return to democracy after a transition that “cannot exceed three years.”

;

;The developments come after the West African regional bloc, while still hoping to solve the crisis in Niger by diplomatic means, said it stands ready to apply force to overturn the July 26 coup if talks fail.

;

;A delegation from the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) arrived in Niger on Saturday to meet with the country's military leaders and ousted President Mohamed Bazoum.

;

;Kathleen Fitzgibbons has arrived in Niamey to lead the US mission in Niger, the US State Department said on Saturday. Fitzgibbons, a career diplomat with extensive experience in Africa, will “bolster efforts to help resolve the political crisis at this critical time.”

;

;Soldiers led by Tiani, chief of the presidential guard, seized power in July and took Bazoum hostage. He remains in detention along with his family and government members. Ecowas has taken a hard line against the soldiers by closing borders, issuing harsh sanctions and activating a standby force.

;

;Top military officers representing the bloc's member-states had completed a plan to enter Niger, Abdel-Fatau Musah, the economic group's commissioner for political affairs, peace and security, said after meetings in Accra, Ghana's capital, on Friday.

;

;The junta and its allies, neighbouring Mali and Burkina Faso – both of which are under military rule – are preparing to counter a possible military intervention.

;

;“In the event of an attack, our leaders have said that we're ready. We're prepared to support Niger,” Burkina Faso's Defence Minister Kassoum Coulibaly told Russia's state-owned news agency, RIA, after the military chiefs' meeting in Accra.

;

;What the Niger coup means for China's presence in the Sahel

;

;

;

;Coup leaders had no intention of collaborating with the Kremlin-backed Wagner mercenary group or harming the deposed president, junta-installed Prime Minister Ali Lamine Zeine told The New York Times.

;

;Niger has been a key Western ally and a relative bastion of stability in one of the world's most volatile regions. The US has a military drone base in the country, and France has about 1,500 troops stationed there, targeting insurgents affiliated with al-Qaeda and Islamic State in cooperation with Nigerien forces.

;

;The landlocked nation, more than twice the size of France, ranks among the least-developed countries. It has a population of over 25 million and one of the highest birth rates in the world.

;

;

;

;Niger's ousted President Mohamed Bazoum met with regional mediators on Saturday in the second encounter with a foreign delegation since the military detained him last month.

;

;Bazoum met with an Ecowas delegation in Niger's capital, Niamey, according to a special adviser to the president.

;

;The junta shared photographs of Bazoum at the meeting. It was only the second time since the coup last month that he was shown outside of confinement.

;

;The regional bloc said it's still hoping to solve the crisis in Niger by diplomatic means. But it stands ready to apply force to overturn the July 26 coup if talks fail, the delegation said.

;

;The junta has previously threatened to prosecute Bazoum with high treason, a crime punishable by death.

; Sun, 20 Aug 2023 09:20:03 +0800 Feeding Monkey King: caring children in China theme park offer bananas to man in deity character costume from classic Chinese novelhttps://www.scmp.com/news/people-culture/trending-china/article/3231387/feeding-monkey-king-caring-children-china-theme-park-offer-bananas-man-deity-character-costume?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.20 09:00;
;;

;Children in a park in China have graduated from feeding real monkeys to offering bananas to a human inside a costume of the Monkey King, a character from the classic 16th century novel Journey to the West.

;

;Video clips of the Monkey King character eating food fed by children through a hole in an artificial hill in a park in northern China's Hebei province went viral on August 16.

;

;The man playing the character – who is also widely known as Sun Wukong in Chinese folklore – is surnamed Yu and is a full-time performer.

;

;In the video, he is performing a passage from the novel in which Sun Wukong is buried under the Five Elements Mountain for 500 years – a punishment from Buddha after he rebelled against heaven, by squeezing himself into the hole in the hill.

;

;Moved by his predicament, several children offered Yu items such as cookies, potato chips, instant noodles, and most commonly, bananas – which are stereotypically regarded as the favourite food of monkeys.

;

;“I'm starving. So delicious,” Yu tells the children, vividly imitating the tone of the Monkey King character shaped in 1980s Journey to the West television dramas adapted from the novel.

;

;The novel was written by Wu Cheng'en during the Ming dynasty (1368 - 1644) , and is regarded as one of the four great novels in Chinese literature.

;

;The mythical adventure tells of the legendary pilgrimage of the Tang dynasty Buddhist monk Xuanzang, who travelled from the empire's capital Chang An, today's Xian city, to the west, including India and Central Asia to seek the Buddhist sutras.

;

;In the company of three disciples, the Monkey King, the half-human, half-pig Zhu Bajie, and sand orc Sha Wujing, Xuanzang suffers all manner of trials and tribulations on their journey.

;

;The novel has been adapted into an array of television dramas and films in the mainland, Hong Kong and even Japan and South Korea.

;

;A Journey to the West drama made in 1986 was the earliest television adaption of the novel.

;

;In the adaptation, The Monkey King character, played by Peking opera actor Liu Xiao Ling Tong, set the standard for amateur Monkey King performers constantly seen nowadays in Chinese parks and at tourist attractions.

;

;Some performers are notorious for tricking tourists to take photos before forcing them to pay.

;

;Yu, however, said he only played the role to promote the Journey to the West culture.

;

;The former soldier has been playing the role for years, and other than acting in the park, he has also performed other chapters, such as Real and Fake Monkey King, on the street, at commercial events and in live-streams.

;

;“What a nice job, with free food and accommodation,” one online observer said.

;

;“It is rare to see a job which contains so much happiness nowadays,” said another.

;

;“By being fed too much, one day he might be able to play Zhu Bajie,” quipped a third.

; Sun, 20 Aug 2023 09:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong heatwave prompts calls for cooler prisons, but lawmakers draw line at air conditioning for inmateshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3231644/hong-kong-heatwave-prompts-calls-cooler-prisons-lawmakers-draw-line-air-conditioning-inmates?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.20 09:00;
;;

;Ever-rising temperatures in Hong Kong have prompted calls for better ventilation in the city's prisons, but activists and lawmakers remained divided over providing inmates air conditioning.

;

;Former Democratic Party lawmaker Emily Lau Wai-hing and opposition activist Raphael Wong Ho-ming urged the Correctional Services Department last week to improve ventilation and cooling arrangements in prisons as Hong Kong would only get hotter with climate change.

;

;Lau also suggested installing air conditioners, an idea shot down by former security chief Lai Tung-kwok, who told the Post: “Prisons don't have air conditioners. That's common sense and our common understanding.”

;

;But Lau, a justice of the peace who visited prisons regularly to check on conditions and collect complaints lodged by inmates, explained her concerns about the heat saying: “This isn't about relaxation, but human rights – the right to live and the right to health.”

;

;She said she did not suggest air conditioning in the past when it was not so hot, but the weather was becoming extremely hot now and some inmates described being damp with perspiration all day.

;

;The Hong Kong Observatory has warned of a “significant long-term increasing trend” in temperatures from August to October. It predicted earlier that this summer could be one of the top 10 hottest summers on record.

;

;Last year, the city had 52 “very hot days”, when the maximum temperature hit 33 degrees Celsius (91.4 Fahrenheit) or higher, the second highest annual total on record. Hong Kong tallied 29 “very hot days” in its first seven months of this year.

;

;In the southern United States, high temperatures and heat-related deaths among prisoners have resulted in family members of inmates and prison advocates calling for air conditioning in jails.

;

;The Texas Tribune reported at least nine prisoner deaths from reported heart attacks or cardiac events in prisons without air conditioning on days when outdoor temperatures exceeded 37.8 degrees from mid-June to mid-July this year. Most of the state's 100 prisons have partial or no air conditioning.

;

;'Life's better in prison': rising cost of living hits Hong Kong's poor hard

;

;Sharon Dolovich, a law professor from the University of California, Los Angeles and director of its prison law and policy programme, told the Post that prison authorities should consider air conditioning to provide a humane correctional environment amid climate change.

;

;She disagreed that providing physical comfort in prisons would reduce the deterrent effect, saying there was no evidence that criminals considered the conditions in jail when committing a crime.

;

;Ultimately, she said, the deprivation of liberty and banishment from society were “a deeply harmful punishment to inflict on anybody”.

;

;There have been no reports of heat-related deaths among Hong Kong prisoners, but Lau and activists who had been jailed and visited inmates in recent years said the city's prison authorities could do more.

;

;They said prisoners had to suffer sweltering heat made worse by old prison buildings with poor ventilation and insufficient cooling measures.

;

;The Correctional Services Department said it had added fans and allowed its officers to buy handheld fans and cooling towels for inmates.

;

;Replying to a letter from Lau, a spokesman for the Correctional Services Department said it had added or replaced 2,300 fans across all 29 correctional facilities since 2020, installed more than 15,000 electric fans and put more than 1,600 roller fans with anti-suicide designs in cells.

;

;It also began retrofitting gates and windows at Stanley Prison in 2018 to improve ventilation, with 300 gates and 1,000 windows replaced so far.

;

;The spokesman said other measures included using heatproof paint for buildings and installing solar panels or plants on roofs where suitable.

;

;Figo Chan Ho-wun, a former convenor of the now-disbanded Civil Human Rights Front who was jailed 22 months for offences related to the city's 2019 social unrest, recalled developing heat rash and waking up in the middle of the night during summer when he was at the Lai Chi Kok Reception Centre.

;

;“The heat rash was on my arms, body, inner thighs, even on my back. It was really tough,” he said. “You couldn't pull yourself together to write letters, you couldn't read, you would sweat just sitting there.”

;

;'Threat' of prison visitors to be investigated: Hong Kong security chief

;

;The conditions were slightly better when he was transferred to Shek Pik Prison and was in a dormitory, not confined in a single-person cell.

;

;He urged authorities to at least consider offering cool water to inmates, as only hot water or tea were available when he was in prison.

;

;Raphael Wong, a former chairman of the League of Social Democrats who was jailed four times for protest-related offences, agreed that the ventilation in dormitories was acceptable.

;

;But he asked prison authorities to improve conditions across institutions and holding areas for inmates. He suggested having shower areas in communal spaces, such as canteens, for inmates to cool down before or after meals.

;

;Two lawmakers rejected Lau and Wong's proposals, saying the prison authorities had already done what they could to improve conditions for prisoners during summer.

;

;Pepper spray used to stop prison fight between 3 Hong Kong inmates

;

;Former security secretary Lai and Gary Chan Hak-kan, who chairs the Legislative Council's security panel, said air conditioning was a luxury not enjoyed by many Hongkongers.

;

;“I have great reservations about installing air conditioning, as resources are precious and after all, inmates are serving sentences inside. They are not there for enjoyment,” Chan said.

;

;As for the suggestion to have more shower areas, Lai said that would strain manpower needed to oversee showers and the resulting damp would be another issue to deal with.

;

;But he was confident the authorities would consider individual requests for more showers.

;The Philippine armed forces said it would again seek to resupply troops stationed in a rusty World War 2-era ship on a reef in the South China Sea, after China blocked a previous attempt with water cannons.

;

;“This exercise of our sovereign rights and jurisdiction is a testament to our firm belief in the rules-based international order that underpins regional peace and stability,” armed forces spokesperson Medel Aguilar said in a statement.

;

;Manila filed a diplomatic protest against Beijing this month after China's coastguard used water cannon and “dangerous” moves to prevent the Philippines from sending supplies to a handful of troops in the Second Thomas Shoal.

;

;China claims almost all the South China Sea, an assertion rejected internationally, while Malaysia, Vietnam, Brunei, Taiwan and the Philippines have various claims to certain areas.

;

;Manila calls on all relevant parties to respect its sovereignty and jurisdiction over its maritime zones, Aguilar said, adding that Manila supports the peaceful settlement of disputes.

;

;China's foreign minister urges Philippines to work with Beijing

;

;China's embassy in Manila did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The Chinese coastguard said on August 7 it had told the Philippines not to send ships to the shoal and not to send “construction materials used for large-scale repair and reinforcement” to the warship.

;

;The Philippines intentionally grounded the warship in 1999 as part of its sovereignty claim to the shoal, which lies within its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.

;

;The planned resupply mission “is a clear demonstration of our resolve to stand up against threats and coercion, and our commitment in upholding the rule of law”, the armed forces said.

;

;In 2016, an international arbitration award invalidated China's sweeping claim to almost the entire South China Sea.

;

;China, which does not recognise the ruling, has built man-made islands with airstrips and surface-to-air missiles in the South China Sea.
